choices.C: A dataset is a built-in or third party source; presets group XDR data fields.
choices.D: A dataset is a third-party data source; presets are built-in data source.
choices.B: A dataset is a database; presets is a field.
choices.A: A dataset is a Cortex data lake data source only; presets are built-in data source.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I agree with the link listed below

Selected Answer: C
C

https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-XQL-Language-Reference/Datasets-and-Presets

Datasets - The standard, built-in data source that is available in every Cortex XDR instance is the xdr_data dataset.This dataset is comprised of both raw EDR events reported by the Cortex XDR agent, and of logs from different sources such as third-party logs. 

Presets - Presets offer groupings of xdr_data fields that are useful for analyzing specific areas of network and endpoint activity.

comments.content:
I agree with "C" as the answer.
Datasets can contain Cortex XDR data but also third-party data; presets are predefined configurations that help to simplify and standardize the process of creating reports and/or visualizations based on the data source (dataset)

discussion.content:
Use preset to use a pre-defined datasets in which data is stored from console description
Answer: D

questions.question_text: What is the difference between presets and datasets in XQL?

choices.C: Unit 42 is responsible for threat research, malware analysis and threat hunting
choices.B: Unit 42 is responsible for the configuration optimization of the Cortex XDR server
choices.A: Unit 42 is responsible for automation and orchestration of products
choices.D: Unit 42 is responsible for the rapid deployment of Cortex XDR agents

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the Unit 42 team?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
- DLL Protection can help, but it might not cover all the behavioral aspects of sophisticated attacks like Cobalt Strike.
- Malware Scan is a reactive measure, and not preventive.
- IOCs of malicious files can help to detect and prevent but is not as comprehensive as behavioral protection.

Right answer here is "D".
BTP will prevent any pattern and/or suspicious behavior indicative of an attack.

Selected Answer: C
voting is C

choices.C: Create IOCs of the malicious files you have found to prevent their execution.
choices.B: Conduct a thorough Endpoint Malware scan.
choices.A: Enable DLL Protection on all servers but there might be some false positives.
choices.D: Enable Behavioral Threat Protection (BTP) with cytool to prevent the attack from spreading.

questions.question_text: Cortex XDR is deployed in the enterprise and you notice a cobalt strike attack via an ongoing supply chain compromise was prevented on 1 server. What steps can you take to ensure the same protection is extended to all your servers?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - This is the common actions performed by cybercriminals, extort a payment or cause damage to the company, embarassment might be the case yeah but there can be some other reasons aside from the money,

questions.question_text: Why would one threaten to encrypt a hypervisor or, potentially, a multiple number of virtual machines running on a server?

choices.A: To extort a payment from a victim or potentially embarrass the owners.
choices.D: To potentially perform a Distributed Denial of Attack.
choices.B: To gain notoriety and potentially a consulting position.
choices.C: To better understand the underlying virtual infrastructure.
